name: Primordia
description: Life has ceased. Man is but a myth. And now, even the machines have begun to fail. Lead Horatio Nullbuilt and his sarcastic sidekick Crispin on a journey through the crumbling world of Primordia, facing malfunctioning robots, ancient secrets, and an implacable, power-hungry foe.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP2 or above Processor: Pentium or higher processor  Memory: 64 MB Hard disk space: 1.5 Gb  Video Card: DirectX 5 or above compatibility

reviews.review_text: a very solid point and click adventure that doesnt hold your hand, but also at least gives you Crispin so you arent ever lost on the way.  the music ranges from desolate to haunting and gives a full sense of a dying world and sounds like its from shortly after the 16bit era.  the visuals are very unique and asymmetrical. bringing the beauty of a more organic design to it's cast of robotic wonders.  and the cast themselves are very animated, and unique. they all gives a very distinct feeling. some come across as zealotus misionaries, others as military wardware given life, and theres even a bit of robotic love thrown in there to blur the line between emotion and robotics.  very happy with this game.

'Primordia' had a story so good, I had to come back and play it again to see some of the other endings. Many of the most thought-provoking events make references to issues that have kept me awake before. It's interesting to experience a game that has me thinking about it for a time after the ending credits.  There are some audio issues after using Steam's overlay UI, but the game's pretty polished aside from that glitch. The puzzles are good, but the world is a little empty. However, the animated characters are entertaining and keep things interesting. The artwork and voiceover work is also amazing.  If you want a good story that's told with a classic style point-and-click adventure game, then this is it.
A game about being human, but as a robot.  Amazing 12/10
Wow! Just as good as any great 1991 era point and click adventure. Story, atmosphere, characters, art -- and it has like 7 different endings, and they were all great. Super recommend.

This is what a point-and-click adventure should be. Story, characters, dialogue, challenging puzzles, atmosphere, art style. The only bad thing about this game is that it eventually ends. Until that point, it is an absolute treasure.  The banter between Horatio and Crispin is probably the best part of the story. Anyone who was ever a fan of the classic Lucasarts point-and-click adventures should get this game at once.

★★★★☆  Everything is spot on here: Story, voice acting, score and graphics. The best thing for me: the puzzles are logical so far. I always expect this of 'point&clicks' and often get very disappointed early on.  Make sure to run 'winsetup.exe' in your local game content folder  to setup the graphics and other options before you run the game.    “Who says androids got no hearts?” ― Judd Trichter, Love in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction    ★★★★☆

One of the best indie games released in 2012 and a treat for fans of the adventure genre. Everything, from the captivating plot to the beautiful graphics, is excellently done. The Puzzles offer a lot of variety, the soundtrack is fitting, the voice-acting outstanding, the characters are likable and the exceptionally well-written dialogue couldn't have been better.

An amazing cyberpunk point & click adventure filled with humour, the voice acting is simply fenomenal, and all the characters are so unique. The atmosphere is absolutely fabulous, it reminds me alot of 'Beneath a Steel Sky' which is also an amazing point & click that i absolutely loved. The companion robot´s voice could sound a little more robot´ish, but once you get used to it, you´ll find yourself completely immerged into the games storyline as horatio and is companion struggle to get their stolen item back. I seriously recommend this game to anyone that loves a good story and/or Cyberpunks. This is without a doubt, a must have. - 8/10
More of a pixel hunting game. Puzzles aren't that hard, it's just hard to find stuff for puzzles. Otherewise: superb athmosphere and writing. A good deal while it's on sale, full price- not so much

This game will make you think. Not only is the story executed so well, it makes you think philosophically about ideas like majority rules, utilitarinism (chosing to benefit the society over an individual who may deserve it) and moral absolutism (Abiding by the law is imperative no matter what)

I've never been an extremely huge fan of point-and-click puzzle games, but Primordia caught my attention, initially due to the attractive art style and the story teaser. So I gave it a try, and was blown away by how much I absolutely enjoyed it. It's your standard point-and-click; you collect items, open your inventory, and can combine items or use them on characters or objects in the world to progress. So there's little to mess up when it comes to controls, and Primordia succeeds there.  The game is set some ambiguous number of years in the future. The world is inhabited by robots, no sign of organic life anywhere. You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot designed to build and repair. While aboard your ship, the Uniic, you are attacked by a strange robot and stripped of your ship's power core. Left without transportation and limited power keeping you running, you are left with no other option but to wander out into the world, trying to track down a power source, or as a last resort, enter the city of Metropol, 'the city of glass and light.' Not much is known about Metropol, other than there is supposedly unlimited power for everyone. Still, Horatio has his reserves about entering the city; despite his logic-driven robot nature, he doesn't trust the place. As I mentioned, the art style was much of what first intrigued me, and it's prevalent throughout the game. It's designed to look very old-school and pixelated, but the amount of detail that can be projected by so few pixels is astounding, not to mention the general apocalyptic dystopian feel it gives off, which as a fan of Fallout, I enjoyed all too much.  Overall this was one of those games that gave me that feel of reading a really good book; I'd sit down and play and not want to put it down until I found out what happened next. The only problems I had were a few vague or confusing puzzles, in which I had to resort to the old 'try everything with everything on everything' play method common to point-and-click games. Aside from that, the game offers multiple endings, some far more underwhelming than others, which left me feeling a tad unsatisfied. Still, the game was extremely enjoyable, and one of the few games that I'd almost like to forget playing so I could enjoy it all over again.

One of the best Point and Click games I have EVER played! From the environment to Horatio's character development and to the story, everything was set perfectly to match each other and resulting in something unique and excelllent in its very own way.  I give it a 9 out of 10.  PS: There is more than 4 Endings, Enjoy!
Compeling Story Great Voice Acting Fun and diverse Characters Lots of possible endings  A great game

Probably one of the best, if not THE BEST, cyberpunk game out in the world.  Fan of the cyberpunk genre and dystopian settings? Can handle a resolution of 320x200? Nostalgic point and click lover?  If at least two of those can be answered with 'yes' then this game is prefect for you.

An absolutely beautiful and unique adventure game. You're absolutely garanteed to get sucked into the very rich and compelling world, the characters are memorable and I got super attached to them. Plus, there's Logan Cunningham. 'Nuff said.

Best point-and-click game I've ever played. The puzzles are challenging and require patience but aren't as frustrating as point-and-click games made in the 90's - some can be solved in multiple ways and may effect the ending of the game. The storyline is extremely captivating and offers a pretty different look at religion despite being a sci-fi game through and through.  I highly suggest not reading any spoilers! This game is all about the immersion.  9.5/10

This game has an excellent story and a unique and interesting setting filled with charmingly colorful characters. It is thoughtful and meaningful, and addresses some serious theological and philosophical points, while remaining mysterious and exciting (most of the time). However, I found the gameplay to be very lacking, in a number of ways. I'm now going to complain about all the things I need to complain about, but do please recall that I actually enjoyed this game :)  The puzzles in this game were difficult, and not in a good way. While many of them had 'cool' solutions - which would be awesome in a movie, for example - they were often not cleanly solvable, in the sense that they were the only plausible solution and made everything 'make sense' when you figured it out. For me, a lot of the reason I want to play a puzzle game is for that awesome feeling of everything coming together when I figure it out. This is not the sort of game that does that for me. Here's a few of the problems that I saw:  1. Trying to create a clever solution rather than a good puzzle. The solutions to puzzles are often the sort of zany solutions that are fun to watch heroes think of in movies, but not reasonable to force the player to think of. In other words, they don't feel like THE solution, just A solution (and yet in the confines of the game, they are THE solution). 2. Tooooo many items. Unlike a lot of games, in Primordia you almost never get an item taken out of your inventory when you are done using it. By the end of the game, I have so much stuff in my inventory that the task of getting through a locked door has dozens of reasonable-sounding solutions - crowbar, plasma torch, signal transmitter to pick the lock, etc, etc - but only one of them is right (and it's probably none of the standard things I've learned how to do throughout the game, because that would be to easy). 3. Generic, reusable items. This is one of my pet peeves in puzzle games. When you have a generic item like a hammer, there's a trillion and five ways that the player can think of to use this item. Even if the game designer could think of all of those, allowing those solutions would make many of their puzzles too easy. Anyway, this game is full of generic items that you use again and again throughout the game (but are never allowed to use when you think of it). 4. Confusing items. I had a whole bunch of electronic gadgets and doodads that it took me a long time to figure out how they worked - a signal transmitter, a decryption device, a memory reader, etc. All of these could be used only in very specific circumstances (i.e. as far as I can tell, the memory reader can only be used to access memories from a severed robot head - which you encounter in this game a lot more than you would think!), but this information is never explicitly told to you (I never really figured out what the rules for the decryption device were). 5. Just too much going on at once. The game is basically divided into two parts. During each part, you slowly unlock more areas, and then can travel freely between all areas that you have unlocked during that part, which by the end of each part results in a huge environment in which to look for a small number of remains tasks.  The end result of all of this was that I played the game with a walkthrough constantly ready. And I do not regret it :) Most of the things I had to get help on ('most' because I started getting lazy near the end), I think I would have felt frustrated rather than satisfied if I took the time to solve myself.  The interface is unfathomably archaic and unintuitive. For example, the process of using an item - one of the most base necessities of a point and click game - requires (1) hovering near the top of the screen to open the tool bar, (2) selecting the inventory button to open your inventory, (3) selecting the item from the inventory, (4) clicking outside the inventory to close it, then finally (5) clicking on the thing in the world that you want to use the item on. On all the interfaces mentioned, there are also many confusing and sometimes unnecessary/duplicate buttons. The datachron (which automatically takes notes on things you have learned) has a horrific interface that looks something like an old school gameboy, with giant text on a tiny screen, and buttons (that you have to click with your mouse) for scolling up and down. Similarly, the signal transmitter - on which you frequently need to set a 4-digit number to transmit - is pretty obnoxious, requiring you to click on the left and right sides of two dials (not even buttons that you can see, so it's hard to find the sweet spot to actually click on) - one to cycle through numbers, and one to cycle through DIGITS. DIGITS.  All that being said, however, I think this game is definitely worth playing for the story alone, which like I said is fantastic.

A solid point-and-click adventure with very cool worldbuilding. Like every Wadjet Eye game, the graphics and sound leave a bit to be desired but the writing is great and the puzzles themselves keep Adventure Game Moon-Logic to a merciful minimum.
The first point and click I've ever finished. Great aesthetic, well written dialogue, puzzles that make you feel clever without being overly obtuse. It's an amazing game.
An immersive story-based adventure game. My only problem with this game is that it wasn't longer. Please make a sequel.

I loved this game. A story that doesn't focus on humans but the things we left behind. A great story, simple but it holds your interest. The puzzles are easy for the most part a few with well hidden clues might cause a few problems. Not to hard to figure out if you think about them though. The main characters are lovable crispin is the comic relief and Horatio is the serious one but he cracks a few jokes. I can't really give it justice it's one of those games you have to play on your own to understand.

Primordia's robot driven post-apocalyptic setting is a great twist on your standard post-war stories. Even though the characters in the game are robots they retain many human properties that makes them quite relatable. To add to this, their human traits are merged with some very interesting quirks based on what purposes they were coded for. This makes almost every character you meet really interesting and memorable, and also drives a lot humor in the game. In particular, the bond between the playable character Horatio and his creation and best friend Crispin is consistently entertaining thoughtout the whole game. It's not just the setting that's great though, the writing and story in general is fantastic, and the voice acting is amazing.  The gameplay draws really well from the setting too. Scavenging for spare parts and pieceing machines together might feel pretty familiar to anyone who has played an adventure game before, but because of the setting and design of the game all of this feels really organic and fluid. It helps that there are core items in the game aren't simply used once and then thrown away, but instead you are gathering an array of tools (Your friend Crispin being one of them!) that you will keep reusing throughout the whole game. There is still the odd puzzle that had solutions I wouldn't have thought of and got me turning to a guide, but I would put this down to my own impatience rather than design faults of the game. I never really took the time to think things out completely as I was too compelled to move forward with the story!  Long story short, I would strongly recommend this game. The only negative thing I can think of is that I had a couple of very minor technical issues that were resolved easily. If you have any interest in point-and-click adventures or story-driven games in general I wouldn't hesitate to pick this one up.

There are very few point-and-click games I'd play through twice. This is one of them.  Great artstyle, fun characters, and a narrative with a bit of intrigue. Definitely worth your time if you are in the market for this genre.

Somehow I never rated this game while I'd played it before buying it and let me tell you it was one of the most amazing gaming experiences I've ever had. A truly unique art style, awesome writing, characters and this entire world... Good puzzles, several endings... It's one of those games that you'll never forget.

This game is awesome. Really intelligently written.The auther said he took inspiration from Fallout and Planescape: Torment, and it shows. There's a few nicely done call backs to those games too. If you're in the mood for a good story and some puzzle solving to go with it, I strongly recommend this.
A gem that you can't afford to miss if you like the genre.

Primordia is a point and click adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic world strewn with pieces of machinery. You play as Horatio Nullbuild, who has a rather peaceful existence ruined when a powerful robot steals the power source of his ship. Horatio and his companion Crispin leave their home and head for the city of glass and light - Metropol. Here, you will uncover secrets of your past and gain a better understanding of humans who previously walked there.  Primordia does not reinvent the genre, it is a sci fi adventure game that offers a dark and meaningful story - something lost in some modern point and click games. The game provides excellent atmosphere, a rich script, solid puzzles and an art style that is really captivating. It is the sort of game that tries to restore the classic point and click genre and I believe it has truly nailed it. It feels like the 90's, but shows that with careful animations, voice acting and intricate details, that 'modern' resolutions and graphics are not always necessary.  I wanted to find out more and had to see the different endings, take different paths and look for more information online. The only fault would be that it is perhaps too short, especially if you are used to classic adventure games. Some puzzles were pretty difficult and there were a few moments of 'That doesn't make much sense', though that's something I always expect from these games.  It is not really going to interest people who don't play point and click games. It is for people who miss games like The Dig, Beneath a Steel Sky and maybe even the classic Fallout games (in terms of atmosphere). It has replay value, great soundtrack, top storytelling and is certainly difficult enough to stump you in a few places. Highly recommended.

This is one of my favorite adventure games ever. I loved the old Lucas Arts games like The Dig and this reminds me of those. The characters and story are intriguing and the voice acting is great. I really hope we can get a sequel some day!
wow! Just WOW! Original storyline and a must play for point and click adventure lovers out there!
excellent game very funny, only down side is it ended to fast

Primordia is fantastic.   This game is a must play for anyone who enjoyed the point and click adventure games of the past. If you have never tried a point and click, this is the best example of one you could ever hope to encounter.  The story was extremely well written, and the progression was perfect. You really feel like you are developing the story and game as you play, as well as learning about yourself in the process.  This game had me both happy and sad at the end of the game. I was elated to have played such a game, and devastated that it was over.  Horatio and Crispin have a life of their own, and you really couldn't ask for better leads.  If you were ever a fan of the point and click adventure games from Sierra, this game is dead on.

Beautifully done, despite being made with pixels. These aren't the pixels of old, though, and the highly detailed backgrounds and characters will pull you in. Multiple endings, a rich world history and mythology, hours of replay, and the low cost makes it a great deal.

Excellent adventure game in a very interesting and atmospheric dystopian future where robots rule the remains of earth, or rather try to survive in them. Awesome and well written characters who maintain the balance between the dark atmosphere of the desolate world around them and a robot's take on humour. Also, some really nice references to Fallout and others.

This game surprised me. I went in expecting another tedious point-n-click, but was quickly sucked into the world that is Primoridia. You play a robot named Horatio that is on a quest for the rather simple goal of finding his home's battery. What ensues is a storyline that unveils a history and lore rooted in a mixture of 'God and his creation', aiming forward with questions of freewill and the role of the State within a society. All the while, Horatio simply wants his power core.   A brilliant, rich and enticing game. It asks more questions that it answers, while playing with your imagination and leaves you wanting more from this universe. All in all, if you're looking for a game that challenges your logic and problem-solving skills, while experiencing a well-developed world and excellent cast of characters, look no further.
Primordia is the most enjoyable point & click adventure I've played. Interesting characters, compelling plotline, good voice acting, and wonderful music and art.
Great puzzler with loveable characters. If you like machinarium and similar games this ones right up your alley!
Excellent, thought-provoking story.

This game will take you by your hand, like a good novel, and will go with you on a rather unique and intriguing journey.  My only regret is, that I waited this long to actually buy this game.  Once I came to the end of this game, which was very satisfying, I really wanted more. I would hope for a sequel in one way or another.

INCREDIBLE/10   Only, WHY OH WHY WAS THIS SUCH A SHORT GAME?!????? The story had such a richness- It felt like a demo of a game I can't wait to explore.  One of THE most interesting dystopian robot scifi settings to date.

Primordia is one of the best Adventure games I have played in a long time and is heartily recommended for fans of beneath a stell sky, machinarium or anyone who likes cyberpunk/bladerunner-aesthetics.
find that power core.  also buy this when it isnt on sale, give this studio all your money so they can continue making good games. primordia is excellent.   11/10 power cores
If anyone is looking for a good old-fashioned point-and-click game with a beautiful environment, a interesting storyline, and puzzles with multiple solutions, Primordia has all of those and more.

Highly recommended  The game has many strong points from its lovely artwork that fits the theme to a T, a well written add the intriguing story that mixes good pace with foreshadowing, The puzzles are logical and in most cases can be simply solved with careful thought and the voice acting only serves to strength the atmosphere.  The only issues I have had with the game were a single crash during the intial time I ran the game and a slight bug if you try to use the steam overlay.

I came into this game not expecting much. I thought the art style was pretty neat, but as far as the story or gameplay, I really was not hoping for much. However, this game was amazing. Although at first- and even throughout much of the game, as many of the characters are lighthearted- somewhat comedic, the game's oppressive and bleak dystopian atmosphere was surprisingly dark and depressing. The game also did a good job at emotionally connecting you to Horatio and Crispin, which, really surprisingly for me, helped create a really sad feeling later on in the game. Very highly recommended. In fact, it may be one of my favorite games.

INCREDIBLE/10   Only, WHY OH WHY WAS THIS SUCH A SHORT GAME?!????? The story had such a richness- It felt like a demo of a game I can't wait to explore.  One of THE most interesting dystopian robot scifi settings to date.
Chilling and beautiful atmosphere, gripping story, lovable characters (most of the time), and interesting puzzles. This is my fave indie game so far.
Very good. Recomend to anyone wishing for a story.
Oh god, I loved it. I wanna have babies with this game.

Absolutely fantastic game. Anyone who played Freddy Fish or Pajama Sam as a kid will fall in love with Primordia!  Definitely on the short side, but the puzzles are extremely well done and challenging, yet still fair.  10+ possible endings.  I hope there is a sequel in the future

You can beat it in a day but you'll wish you couldn't. This takes everything that was great from the glory days of adventure games, including some stunning pixel art, and refines it to perfection. The story is excellent, the puzzles actually make sense and are quite fun, and the characters and dialogue are wonderful. No adventure game fan should miss this.

I absolutely adored this game. The story was compelling enough for me to feel invested without becoming so complicated that I lost interest. The visuals and sound track are stunning. The dialogue is well written. Crispin is a little talkative but I grew to enjoy his company. The puzzles have a range of difficulties.   My only issue with the game was it crashed on my a few times. I was able to fix the crashing but there was still a glitch were the images of my inventory looked like colored blocks. It did not really effect the game play though.  Would highly recommend.
A beautifull pixeled adventure with a rather interesting story and an unsually straightforward point and click system

Loved the story, so many endings and alternate routes you'll have to look them up to get all of them. Easy to get lost without a guide and sometimes some of the dialogue didn't cue properly so I missed entire conversations (some important to the plot), turns out you have to turn off Steam overlay for this particular game so be careful of that. Most of the puzzles and items you had to combine actually made sense, unlike a lot of other point-and-click games. Even though you could finish this game in one sitting, the characters are extremely likeable and the atmosphere makes you feel like you're really in on this by yourself.

definetely worth checking out,the story is intriguing,the dialogue is clever,and the banter between the 2 main characters is great to listen to,however expect to have to check a wiki at least once,some of the puzzles REALLY go against anything a normal person would think

Primordia is my first 'proper' Point and Click and as such I did have some trouble with some of the puzzles, but I am someone who is completly new to it with only The Walking Dead as a prior Point and Click.  Primordia is heavily story rich. There's so much in the world that I wish I could have explored more so that I might have more knowlege about it, but since it's not importaint to the plot it's touched on at most.    There is an information kiosk that you can look at however. It'll give you information on any topic you can find.     You follow Horatio and Crispin, two robots living out in the dunes, until their power core was stolen by a bigger robot. They embark on a mission to get it back. I don't want to go too deep into story but the ending was one I was very satisfied with. I'm so used to games having a truely happy ending but the endings in Primordia were none of that.    The endings were that of weariness, telling the player that in this world there is no such thing as a happy ending. The world has died and there doesn't seem to be a way to get a kind of renewable resource, and if there is it's just not known.     Primordia was an amazing game, it wasn't too long nor too short. It was just right.

When I first saw this game, I was looking for something similar to machinarium (another point-and-click adventure game) and what I was met with while playing Primordia was not at all disappointing. There are some very unique things that set this game apart from other point-and-click adventure games.  One element that is so different about Primordia is the surprisingly large amount of dialogue that is incorporated into it, unlike most other games of the genre.  Another characteristic that adds to the game is Crispin, the protagonist's 'sidekick' if you would call him that. He adds a sense of humour to the game (although sometimes rather corny) and can offer hints to the player that are valuable, but not always completely revealing of the next course of action that must be taken. Crispin is an often uplifting character in this post-apocalytic setting.  Another trait that won me over is the atmosphere in the game. It seems realistic in the post-apocalyptic setting, and it is one of my favorite things about this game. The backrounds always seem beautifully made.  The puzzles in this game are very engaging and are not always clear-cut which may seem like a bad thing, but I personally enjoy the extra challenge. Not every puzzle is as simple as clicking on one thing and then another. They often include various items and/or certain actions to be taken. This is a huge difference between Primordia and other point-and-click adventure games.  The only complaint I really have about this game is that it seems to include a few creationist concepts that I personally do not agree with. It is brought up through the concept of humanism in the game which is symbolic of today's major religions that believe that a god created humans.  Another piece of this game that I am not fully content with is the way the protagonist moves. It can sometimes seem somewhat clumsy, but I won't be critical about it seeing as how that is how it is with most other point-and-click adventure games.  Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10. It is definitely a worthwhile play for those who like games such as machinarium or other big point-and-click adventure games because of the unique elements it includes.  One last thing I would like to address is that it sometimes has multiple choices that can be made, leading to different outcomes. They do not alwyas have a huge effect on the story, but it adds a sense of independence in the game. I highly recommend that you all look into playing this game :)

Okay so, I honestly despise point and click games and really, any game that isn't 3D and or, open world. But I must say, Primordia is truly an amazing game. The atmosphere, colour choices, soundtracks, art-style and location/character design all fit flawlessly together, the whole game in general is simply perfect. And another thing, I actually didn't come across one single bug or glitch.  This game is beautiful, flawless, atmospheric and well ♥♥♥♥ing worth the $10 out of your bank.  Give. The. Developers. Your. ♥♥♥♥ing. Money. NOW.
Fantastic sci-fi point 'n click adventure with puzzle elements. Really enjoyed the old-school aesthetic :)

Usually I do not have the patience to play retro (i.e. pixelated) point-and-click adventures anymore, nevermind finish them. This one kept me going though and I played it all in one sitting. What kept me going? The setting and the story were original (at least they were to me) and engaging. The gameplay and puzzles were simple enough to not get tedious without being pure pushovers. Most importantly, though, the characters were interesting and absolutely beautifully voiced -- far superior to a recent so-called 'AAA game' that I played where I grew to hate the characters. Not in Primordia: every character was great and the voice actors and sound design was perfect: Horatio, Crispin, Clarity, Ever-Faithful, Gimbal, Goliath, Oswald, Primer, 187th, Memento Moribuilt -- so many awesome voices and dialogues that I enjoyed immensely.
This game was very good. I wish there were more games like this.

Great game. Everything that a point and click RPG should be. I enjoyed the variance in puzzles and that they weren't all given to you without work. I lso liked to ability play with minimal help or lots of it, depending on the puzzle. There were a few puzzles that had harder to follow or find peices than I liked, but it may have just been me. Overall, I greatly enjoyed the experience and would recommend it to anyone.
Great, great point & click. Excellent dialogues, music, atmosphere in general. More possibilities & intrigues than pixels. But hey, isn't that what really matters when you want to remember a game?
Pretty good story with the only real negative being the odd graphics scaling.
Hardcore cyberpunk goodness. 8/10
great story 9/10

Amazing game. It's officially my favorite point and click adventure since Maniac Mansion on the NES. I LITERALLY laughed out loud at parts and shed a tear near the end. Nearly perfectly paced, non-frustrating puzzle game mechanics, GORGEOUS artstyle in the vein of sorta Geiger meets Syd Mead. I can't recommend it enough. 10 out of 10.

Possibly the best point and click adventure I've played in a decade. Certainly the best modern one. Nostalgic and yet refreshingly new. Cleverly written, and chock full of enjoyable characters. The puzzles followed a logic that was immediately understandable, but still required creativity to solve. In short, I loved it.
the Art alone makes it worth it!
Good old point and click take a trip down memory lane and embrace its wonders great story puzzles two thumbs up!

This game was a pleasant surprise, to be certain. I could tell just from looking at the trailer and screenshots of this game that it looked interesting, and that 'Overwhelmingly Positive' next to the user reviews made it seem like a no-brainer. So, finally I picked up this game and boy, I am not disappointed.  Let's get the bad out of the way first.  This game runs in a very small resolution, at least for most modern monitors. The highest resolution possible is 1280x800, which looks best in a window. It was also a bit annoying that the only way I could find to change these settings was by a launcher in the actual folder containing the game files. I only found that much by perusing the game forum when I was disappointed with the resolution.  There isn't much replayability. I can definitely see myself trying this game again to do a few things different, but overall it is a story-driven and therefore linear experience. It has several endings, but most of those endings are decided at your own whim by how you play out the final scenes.  Now, the good.  The obvious first thing you'll notice about this game is that artwork. I found it to be very cool to look at and definitely gives you that feeling of despair - a world wasting away around you as you desperately try to rebuild what you can. You also have atmospheric music that adds to these scenes but mostly stays in the background. It adds a lot, but doesn't overtake it. Instead, it's all just working together to give you an experience.  The voice acting is likewise excellent. The main character and his sidekick both do most of the talking, so it's great to see them so well performed. It's easy to pick up on their personalities and they're both likeable.  I'm always a bit bad at puzzles in games, but I thought the ones here were challenging but always possible. Nothing ever felt frustrating or beyond my abilities to figure out. I did get 'stuck' in a few places where I had no idea what to do, but it usually came down to me not thinking about the situation well enough or remembering details that I simply overlooked. It's worth saying, almost everything matters in this game. There are few things that are superfluous.  Overall it took me about six hours to complete this game. I would have liked for it to be longer, but I could say that for any good game.  If you're interested in this game at all, check it out.

Okay so, I honestly despise point and click games and really, any game that isn't 3D and or, open world. But I must say, Primordia is truly an amazing game. The atmosphere, colour choices, soundtracks, art-style and location/character design all fit flawlessly together, the whole game in general is simply perfect. And another thing, I actually didn't come across one single bug or glitch.  This game is beautiful, flawless, atmospheric and well ♥♥♥♥ing worth the $10 out of your bank.  Give. The. Developers. Your. ♥♥♥♥ing. Money. NOW.

A very good point n click about robots in a post-human world that oozes atmosphere. Think Fallout/Wasteland + Machinarium with more voice acting (starring Logan Cunningham of Bastion fame!) Do mind that it's very much a point n click adventure with all the bad it usually comes with like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t puzzles and impossible to see objects you need to pick up.
Very nice story :)

Awesome Point&Click Adventure! The atmosphere, characters and the soundtrack, everything works so well together and create a stirring story within a melancholic, decaying, yet somehow fascinating world.  The game itself is rather short, but with some quite tricky puzzles and several interesting endings you'll enjoy it long enough. This game is simply addictive.
This game made my head hurt... in a good way. Great pixel art, challenging puzzles including the occasional math and logic problems (ugh!) and supremely voiced robots with god complexes.

First off, I highly recommend this game.  Pros: Fun play experience, decent storytelling, fairly decent voicing of characters, game was priced fairly well.  Cons: Some of the clickables in game aren't readily apparent and in one instance incredibly easy to overlook (elevator control panel at one point in game is a prime example). The game is short (I really wish it had been longer, I didn't want it to end. The game is able to be completed in under 2 hours.)  It's pretty rare when I find a game that I enjoy as much as this one. It is fairly reminiscent of Septerra Core, which is a major plus. The game is well polished and priced quite well for the level of enjoyment you get playing it.

okay i've wanted to recommend this game for a long time now, and the new 'nomination' task of reviewing a nomination of mine would be a good reason to finally go ahead and do it wouldn't it?  primordia has been one of my all time favourites ever since i first played it, it's a point-and-click- adventure game with decent puzzles, a very immersive world, and a story that might not appear that interesting, but it slowly develops into something more, unfolding the further you get into it. the voice acting and sound and the music are all fantastic, and the pixel-art style of the game is done well, and it just nails the dark post apocalyptic world setting. although the main character might not be that relateable, i don't think he's meant to be at least at first, that's another thing about the story, the main character over time learns more about himself and the world he lives in along with the player, which is a nice way to introduce the player to it as well. and another thing, the devs have done everything they could to make this game a good experience, even after it was finished, there was a certain bug in this game that i remember lots of forum threads discussing and the devs have been as supportive as they could (their ability to work with the publisher was a little limited from what i could tell) and eventually they have replied to all the requests to fix it, and it's great to see developers caring about their players so much, it took them a while but they clearly wanted to get it done as fast as possible. it's a shame the sequel/prequel was cancelled, because i would've absolutely loved seeing more of this.  i absolutely recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games, or just this kind of setting in general.

i was drawn to this game from its fantastci and awe inspiering art. The game play and storyt is great, but this a hard game. it has all the old nicks and tinks that most point and clicks have. and makes it rather difficult sometimes to find out what to do. BUt i loved every second of it. It was really emursive and had such a stunning world. it really reminds me of H. R. Gigers work.
Incredible good story. Funny dialogs. New and refreshing riddles.  10/10 would play again.

Golden age of point-and-click / text adventures might be gone, but this title brings you back to early 90's, when greatest classics were born. Primordia is pure 2D pixely adventure with unique art style, gripping story that will leave you thinking, great voiceacting (Logan Cunningham - Bastion) and atmosphere of dystopian future emanating from every single pixel. It should be noted that it shares couple of similarities with Beneath a Steel Sky, another great experience.  Any fan of classic point-n-clickery can't go wrong with this one, as it is one of the best in its genre available on Steam. However it might be a little bit too short if you follow only the most straightforward path and forget to explore the backstory, explore details and solve few optional puzzles.

If you liked those games in the 90s, you will like this one too. It has an amazing story and multiple endings. Remember that the good ending is always possible and is not hard to find. I may play the game again once I forget a little bit the story, just to unlock all achievements. On second play I will activate the option to check what the game developers have to say about game. These thoughts are accessible in each screen as you walk arround. Unfortunately the background noise in Metropol is slightly louder that their voice.

What happens when robots rule the world? Primordia answers that question. After an apocolyptic war, the only thing left is desert, bots, and scrap. Take control of an andriod who seems to have some kind of past with the, city of glass. Help him and his assistant. AKA the floating bomb unravel mysteries, and build a new future. I can say, without any exaggeration, that this is hands down one of the best adventure games I have ever played in my 40 years of life. I binge played it in a day from start to finish and I could not stop. It's amazing. 5 alternate endings, multiple ways to solve certain puzzles, amazing storyline, beautiful ambience and timeline, and fantastic 'life lesson.' 10/10. I wish I could lobotimize myself and forget this game and play it again from the beginning.

Wow, what can I say. As of writing this, Primordia is about 95% positive, and should probably be 99%. Great game, pulled me right in and stayed up 'till 4am finishing in one sitting. Strong contentender for my favorite game. I will say, take your time toward the end, there are some important things you can miss right after the explosion. That's not a spoiler, but you can REALLY easily miss two very important things if you are not careful, it's worth looking at a walkthrough if you don't find them. If you have not played this one, do yourself a favor and just do it. It took me a long time try it because I was kind of on the fence about whether to play a 'point & click'. Now, it makes me look at several other games and wonder if they would be better in this format. No offense to the original Deus Ex, I love that game, but that game would be killer in this format with it's great story & characters. Primordia makes me want to write the story for a P&C game, and I think I will give it a try!!
An enjoyable, retro style adventure game, if a little short.
some puzzles are not as obvious as they should be, but a great story and game.

If you've got a love for the classic point-and-click adventure games, then I would recommend this game. Although fairly short, it offers hard, yet logical puzzles with a rich story that can keep you captivated and wanting to continue. Wadjet Eye has proved itself again with an excellent title.

This is a great apocalyptic point and click adventure where humans are now a myth and robots have inherited the Earth. Absolutely terrific storyline and challenging gameplay - a must buy for those who enjoy the point and click genre.

I'm sorry to say that I was rather disappointed with this game. I think the trailer made me expect too much from it (what else is new). And the first half of the game itself made me expect too much from the second half. I can't really say how without spoiling, unfortunately. Let's just say that I expected some pretty grand moments that the game never even came close to delivering. But I would still recommend this game, as parts of the story are pretty interesting and some of the puzzles and conversations are cool.  I do have to talk about Crispin though. It feels like they tried to make a Wheatley-esque character who follows you everywhere, and is kind of annoying but also endearing and adorable. Unfortunately they made Crispin too much of a smartass, so he comes off as not very endearing, not even remotely adorable, but still quite annoying. His lines also get very tiresome, as they are often just lame puns and jokes, and he doesn't have a very large number of them. And aside from scripted scenes, his comedic presence didn't change in response to the increasingly minatory plot, which often ruined the tone.  Lastly, the voice-acting generally isn't very good. The villain probably has the best voice-acting. The voices themselves? Very good, well-chosen, well-suited to their characters. But the acting itself wasn't very good. It's fairly boring and I got tired of listening to everyone speak pretty quickly. Perhaps this was intentional because they were robots, but you can make someone sound robotic without sacrificing solid, emotive acting (case in point:  Portal ).

A flying metal burrito with a laser pointer takes Horatio’s power core and he ain’t gonna take no ♥♥♥♥ from some ♥♥♥♥ – so he follows the trail of metal burrito to the last thriving city, a city of robots, ran by a hivemind that doesn’t take ♥♥♥♥ from no one. I had taken 6 hours to play through it; however it’s because I’m a ♥♥♥♥♥ and used a walkthrough. Going through without a guide would provide several more hours than what I have listed. Get this, it’s fun and you will enjoy it.

Certainly one of the best point and click Adventures I've played since the nineties!* Both immersive and humerous. The story is Great and told extremely well. the art style is very appealing combining art nouveau and cyberpunk proves a valid design concept, the resolution ould be a tad bit higher tho and animations are a bit of a let down but that's a flaw of many games in the genre. Unlike most P&Cs with inventory, Primordias items are neither randomly taken from the environment(aka taking the banana instead of the wench) nor require absurd combinations, most 'crating' tasks are sensible.  The Help function is a bit wonky, it's hints range from being very specific to being nomore than a slight nudge in the right direction and there are no 'advice levels' or 'search functions'. there is no hotspot highlighter, which may be seen both ways. Ps: Unniic, Genius!  *Probably THE best if you dismiss myst 4 as not a point and click game **I required it once, when I was standing infront of the hotspot. The hotspot was even named 'crystal' -.- ***The is one spot(info booth) where I would have liked an additional voiceover, something Myst 4 did: voice all written text.

Good point and click adventure, in some ways it's a bit like Beneath a Steel Sky. This is a bloody good point and click. Should be more known. Great themes.

I'm not giving a thumbs down because I out and out dislike the game - I'm not not entirely sure if it's worth the trailer hype and full price purchase given the shortcomings. Feels like a spiritual successor of sorts to Beneath A Steel Sky, something I'm surprised more people didn't pick up on. Visually it all works and the music pleasantly chugs along - Along with some humour from Horatio and Crispin.  Here's the problem though; Just as the game allows you to get more comfortable and eager to explore the story more, it stops becoming fun. The middle section of the game has some painful 'swap this for that' puzzle sequences that become a chore, and you are only driven to continue because of the story, and trust me, you will be looking at a walkthrough at some point, some of the puzzles are too obtuse.  It also ends far too soon - overall only having 2 main environments in the whole game is not that satisfying at all, and what could have been quite atmospheric starts to feel a little brownwashed. The character development was never built up long enough for me to feel any emotional connections with the characters, and there were some uninspired and cliched plot turns. Beneath A Steel Sky never varied too much in environment either but at least it stayed enjoyable right to the end. There are multiple paths in the game to take which will lead to different endings - but it really depends on whether you enjoyed the first run to want to do this, and I'm not entirely sure if I want to play this game again for a while. Shame there's no windowed mode either, can appreciate the Lucasarts style resolution/graphics decision but couldn't easily leave the window or tweak anything.  I'm not saying it's a bad game, trust me, it isn't - I would just suggest you wait for it to go on sale, as there's a chance you could be disappointed like I was.

Overall this is a sad case of a game with brilliant elements but too many faults to make it an enjoyable experience. It has the best sense of humour of just about any game I have played. The story is good, though some of the elements don't fit together.  The problems are:   1/ the graphics are terrible. Yes, they have a cute, arty style but they are ridiculously low resolution.   2/ The mechanics are clunky, with slow menus and too much time watching pixellated figures crossing the screen painfully slowly.   3/ Some of the puzzles are good, but a lot of the time I had to use a walkthrough not because a puzzle was difficult but because the game is inconsistent. Most exits are identified by mousing over, but some are only identified if you move the character to the edge of the screen. There is a system of storing info useful for solving puzzles but some of the info stored is irrelevant and some vital info is not stored. To combine items in inventory you pick up A and mouse it over B. You get a message telling you that's a dumb idea, but it turns out you need to pick up B and mouse it over A.
